Authors:
Jaqueline Figueredo de Oliveira Costa, Sandra H Kamei,
Janaine Rossane Araujo Silva, Ana Raphaela Gomes da Silva Miranda,
Mariote dos Santos Brito Netto, Sarah Jacqueline Cavalcanti Silva,
Kamila Camara Correia, Gaus Silvestre Andrade Lima, Iraildes Pereira
Assunção
Title:
Species diversity of Colletotrichum infecting Annona spp. in
Brazil
Keywords:
Annona muricata, Annona squamosa, Colletotrichum
brevisporum, Colletotrichum cliviae, Colletotrichum gigasporum,
pathogenicity
Abstract:
Anthracnose disease caused by Colletotrichum species, is a
limiting factor to the production and commercialization of anonaceous in
different regions of the world. In this study, ninety-six Colletotrichum
isolates were collected from soursop and sugar apple leaves showing
anthracnose symptoms in commercial plantations of the state of Alagoas,
northeastern region of Brazil. To access the initial measure of the
species diversity, the isolates were identified by phylogeny based on
the sequences of the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH)
gene. Representative strains were chosen for identification by analysis
of multigene phylogeny including sequences of the internal transcribed
spacer (ITS) region and actin (ACT), chitin synthase (CHS-1), β-tubulin
(TUB2), calmodulin (CAL), histamine (HIS3), glutamine synthetase (GS),
(GAPDH) genes, morpho-cultural characters and pathogenicity tests. These
analyses allowed the identification of nine species: Colletotrichum
karstii, C. tropicale, C. siamense, C. theobromicola, C. fructicola, C.
gloeosporioides, C. gigasporum, C. brevisporum and C. cliviae. Until now
only C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides and C. theobromicola had been
associated with antracnose in plants of soursop and sugar apple in
Brazil. The C. gigasporum, C. brevisporum and C. cliviae species are
also described for the first time in anonaceous worldwide.
